context: Neopterin, which was first isolated from humans in 1967, has been used as indicator of cell-mediated immunity in pathologic states that are characterized by activation of T-helper type 1 lymphocytes. 42 Elevated neopterin levels have been noted in clinical conditions such as systemic infections, autoimmune diseases, malignancies, renal failure, and cardiovascular disease. 17 Although numerous studies indicate that biochemical markers such as CRP are useful in predicting coronary events, there are some data suggesting that measurements of neopterin alone or in combination with CRP may have better clinical utility. 25 29 Longitudinal follow-up of patients with chronic stable angina has shown that higher levels of neopterin but not CRP were associated with a greater incidence of nonfatal acute myocardial infarction, unstable angina requiring hospitalization or urgent revascularization, and cardiac death. 29 High neopterin levels have also been correlated with morphologically complex coronary lesions 43 even after adjusting for CRP levels, 27 and thus have been used as a marker for risk stratifying patients with acute coronary syndromes. 44 Finally, elevation in serum neopterin and CRP levels is better in predicting major cardiovascular end points than elevation in either marker alone. 25 The prognostic value of neopterin in cardiovascular disease is related to the fact that plaque disruption and thrombogenicity are in part determined by the number of activated T-cells and macrophages contained within atherosclerotic lesions.
